critique this on behalf of a Innovation Support Organizations participant in the program and the funders:
EON Training of Trainers Program Concept Note
Deepening Wellbeing and Engagement in Innovation Support Organizations and their Beneficiaries (May 2023)
Introduction
Through the Entrepreneurship Opportunities Network (EON) program, Bloom is launching a Training of Trainers (TOT) program to provide short-term intensive support and training to five Lebanese Innovation Support Organizations (ISOs), focusing on deepening wellbeing and engagement in these organizations and for the beneficiaries they serve.

The EON (Entrepreneurship Opportunities Network) program is part of the “From Innovation to Creation” project funded by the European Union in collaboration with Bloom and SPARK. The program's main objective is to support innovation, employment, and economic growth in the region, specifically by strengthening the local start-up ecosystem in Lebanon through capacity building for existing and emerging ISOs.

Bloom will select five ISOs for the EON TOT Program in the Summer of 2023.
Objective of the Training of Trainers Program
This project aims to enhance ISOs' capacity by providing tailored capacity development programs that help them deepen their wellbeing and engagement in their organizations and for the organizations that they serve.
Using Bloom’s methodology and tools, the program can successfully enhance the capacity of ISOs and ultimately contribute to the growth of entrepreneurship in Lebanon.
With this program, you can expect the following:
Increased Team Engagement: The tailored activities and personalized wellbeing and engagement plans will help ignite each employee's passion and motivation to contribute meaningfully to the ISO.
Healthier Work Culture: Our program focuses on creating a supportive work environment, addressing employees' challenges, and promoting wellbeing at work.
Enhanced Organizational Performance: With improved engagement levels, the employees will be better equipped to collaborate, innovate, and drive growth, leading to positive impacts on the ISOs’ performance.
Target audience
The target audience for this project is ISOs that provide services to entrepreneurs and startups, such as business incubators, accelerators, co-working spaces, and other similar organizations.
We are additionally coordinating with other partners in the “From Innovation to Creation” project (PPI/AOU, cewas, Berytech) to find complementary ways to build the ecosystem's capacity and ensure collaboration in designing and delivering activities that meet the needs of selected organizations.
A comprehensive list of potential organizations shared with the Spark partners is maintained here: Lebanon Ecosystem Mapping - SPARK - 2023
Outreach and Open House
Once the applications are open, Bloom will launch an outreach campaign to attract and target a broad range of relevant applicants. The campaign will include 
Landing Page: on Bloom.pm developed to use in all communication material, including basic program information, link to the interest form, and other relevant information as deemed necessary. 

Email newsletters and outreach
Newsletter, including a call to action inviting potential partners to apply to the program to a database of 10,000 subscribers accumulated over the years.
Targeted emails to the database of ISOs and their employees using Apollo

A social media campaign on the BloomEMEA social pages to reach out to potential partners consisting of social media posts including information for partners, details about the program, an invitation to join the events, and other information.

Direct outreach to ISOs through emails, LinkedIn messages, and events

Collaborations with relevant organizations and stakeholders to reach a wider audience (including other Spark Partners)
EcoSwitch 
Livelihoods Working Group 
LiveLove - Private Sector Working Group 
3RF / RDCL group 

We aim to launch outreach publicly in Week 1 of June 2023. 
We will already be in touch with most of the ISOs in Lebanon as we send out the mapping survey in the last week of April to learn more about Lebanon's innovation ecosystem and create a clear overview of the existing innovation and entrepreneurship support programs.

We will create a simple form for ISOs to express interest in joining the Open House Period and learn more about the TOT program. The details of the application process are explained in the following section.

We can organize two Open House events that tease some topics we might tackle during the program. Here are some ideas:
Happiness at work (Randa Lebtivity)
Purpose (Nihal Ahmed or Pascal Kolbe)
Mindfulness at work (Vipul Shaha)
Others?
Selection Process
Selection Philosophy
Bloom’s selection process is based on the following principles: 
Identify partners with the most significant potential to work on their capacity building 
Be fair & transparent
Inspire generosity and collaboration between partners. 
Provide value to the community, foster ecosystem engagement
Generate publicity for the program as a by-product
Selection Criteria
The first step of the selection process is clearly defining the selection criteria for the ISOs. The EON program will support 5 ISOs in a tailored capacity development program. 

Selection Considerations:
Partners will be assessed along with the following criteria, though not all are required for the program.



Impact & Inclusion
What difference will the ISO make, and for whom? What is their ability to create durable employment opportunities, and what sort of marginalized communities will be impacted?

Capacity
Do they have demonstrated experience in startup and innovation development and support and the capacity to participate and complete the capacity building program?

Feasibility
Can the capacity development plan be realistically delivered by the end of the program?

Innovation &
Growth Potential
Is the organization willing to engage in a collaborative learning approach with this project and to share program details with AltCity Impact / Bloom and relevant information with other project participants?


Applications are open to all sectors. However, we prefer some impact areas due to their more significant impact on the economy or their potential to succeed in the Lebanese context. 

Areas of Interest:
Social Entrepreneurship: Including supporting enterprises, organizations, and other entities that are engaged in economic, social, and environmental activities to serve the collective and general interest, which are based on the principles of voluntary cooperation and mutual aid, democratic and participatory governance, autonomy and independence, and the importance of people and social purpose over the capital in the distribution and use of surpluses and profits as well as assets. (definition source)
Digitalization includes digitizing business processes, business support to growing MSMEs with a growth-oriented digital/tech product, and digital jobs. (definition source)
Green Entrepreneurship: Including greening of business processes, business support to growing (M) SMEs with a growth-oriented green product, and green jobs. (definition source)
Application Process
Bloom is excited to offer an exciting learning opportunity for people working in entrepreneurship and innovation in Lebanon to deepen wellbeing and engagement within their organizations and with the organizations in their programs, learn from others, and gain skills in areas that are important to them. 

Since most ISOs are invited to complete the mapping survey, we will only request that they submit a short form with standard questions, including
A basic short application on the Bloom platform to give us more details about themselves and the organization
3-4 demographic questions about the individual
3-4 organizational questions about the ISOs
Short answers to these three questions
What are the main challenges you face in your organization in supporting entrepreneurs and startups?
What are your current priorities for wellbeing and engagement, both personally and in your work? 
What kind of wellbeing activities would be most exciting for you? 

These questions will help us shape the program's structure to serve the participants best. The program will include elements to help people in their organizational roles while also supporting their individual growth. 
Selection of Partners 
Based on the applications received, Bloom will select a subset of organizations after reviewing the mapping survey data, the application responses, and their alignment with the selection philosophy and impact priority areas. 
Training of Trainers 
Deepening Wellbeing and Engagement in ISOs and their Beneficiaries
Our methodology helps people and teams identify their purpose and build towards enhanced shared success. We use reflective practices, personal and professional development assessments, and a library of activities designed to help the employees thrive at work holistically. 

We focus on fostering self-awareness and identification of purpose at work, effective communication, collaboration, resilience, and personal growth – all critical skills for modern hybrid word environments. These tools, including recent integrations with AI,  will allow participants to facilitate and support their organization’s ongoing growth and development.

Three fundamental principles of a successful Bloom program are:
Our values and strengths power our performance: We help participants identify their sources of meaning at work that unlocks energy and capacity for committed learning and development in their “missions.”
Action-based learning loops: Participants are guided to design a “mission” every two weeks. A mission is a performance objective they want to achieve each cycle, including reflecting on past learnings and planning the next best steps.
Learning by doing together: Promote collaboration and mutual support, primarily online, since usually two heads are better than one.
Program Structure
Participants receive introductory information by email. 

Pre-workshop assessments 
We will invite the five organizations to take the Wellbeing & Engagement and ACAT assessments in July and develop their Wellbeing & Engagement plans. 

Host a 2-hour participatory online workshop reviewing challenges, priorities, and goals, and setting action plans … and direct focused adaptive learning during the workshop.  
Participants will set their priorities based on their assessment results and develop an action plan for the program.

Two weeks of self-guided implementation 
Participants will apply the tools and techniques that they learned in the online workshop while working on achieving the milestones in their action plans

Follow-on 2-hour participatory online workshop, reviewing progress and setting next-stage action plans
Participants will review their progress in their action plans and we will address any blockers they are facing in implementation

Two weeks of self-guided implementation 
Participants will apply the tools and techniques that they learned in the online workshop while working on achieving the milestones in their action plans

One additional group session to wrap up 

A 40-minute 1-on-1 coaching session for up to 5 people in each ISO

Post-assessments: Wellbeing & Engagement and ACAT

Conference: Does wellbeing improve welldoing?
In the last week of September, we will organize a learning conference to present the post-assessment results and preliminary findings.
Incentives
To encourage participation in the program, we could offer the following incentives:
Certification of completion
Social Media Visibility on Bloom’s media channels
Speaker opportunity at the September conference 

Timeline
The program will be implemented over five months, with the following milestones:
Pre-Program Planning & Preparations
Design TOT approach, including selection criteria: By the end of May
Prepare for outreach: By the end of May

Outreach / Open House
Outreach for local innovation support orgs: Early June
Open House activities: Mid-June to End of June
Selection of organizations: End of June

Training of Trainers
Assessments: Weeks 1 and 2 in July
Organizational Development Workplans: Week 3 in July
Implementation: Week 4 in July and Week 1 in August
Follow-on workshop: Week 2 in August
Implementation: Weeks 3 and 4 in August
Follow-on workshop: Week 1 in September
1-on-1 coaching: Week 2 in September
Post-assessment: Week 3 in September
Learning Conference: Week 4 in September

Wrap up and M&E
Pre and post assessments analysis: October
Main roles
The following roles would be involved in the implementation of the project:
Programs Lead: responsible for overall program management and implementation
Dara
Training Lead: responsible for supporting the capacity-building program
Bilal
Training Manager: responsible for developing the curriculum in collaboration with training experts
Claude
Mentor Manager: responsible for finding mentors
Salem
Comms: responsible for developing communication messaging and channels to promote the program and engage with ISOs
Jad
Events: responsible for planning and executing the learning retreat
Steph
Community Manager: responsible for building partnerships and relationships with the organizations
Recruiting
M&E: program evaluation and reporting
Ghina

As an AI, I don't have personal experiences but I'll analyze the presented concept note from the perspectives of both a participant in the Innovation Support Organizations (ISO) program and a funder of the program. Here's my critique:

**From the ISO participant's perspective:**

Pros:
1. *Focus on Wellbeing and Engagement:* This is highly appreciated as it indicates that the program is not only about increasing the efficiency of ISOs, but also about improving the workplace culture and personal wellbeing of employees.
2. *Tailored Programs:* The program promises to be adapted to the needs of the individual ISOs, which shows a high level of flexibility and attention to individual needs.
3. *Clear Objectives and Outcomes:* The concept note clearly outlines what the ISO can expect to achieve from the program, including increased team engagement, healthier work culture, and enhanced organizational performance.

Cons:
1. *Demands on Time and Resources:* The TOT program, while beneficial, might require significant time and resource commitment from the ISO. Details about the exact time commitment required would be helpful.
2. *Limited Number of Participants:* With only five ISOs selected, the competition might be intense. It might be discouraging if an organization does not make it into the final selection.
3. *Lack of Post-Program Support:* Although there is a comprehensive plan for the program and assessment stages, the concept note doesn't address post-program support or follow-up. How will the growth and development be sustained after the program ends?

**From the funder's perspective:**

Pros:
1. *Alignment with Objectives:* The program aligns well with the aim of supporting innovation, employment, and economic growth in the region.
2. *Inclusivity and Transparency:* The open selection process and clear criteria demonstrate a commitment to transparency and inclusivity.
3. *Thorough Planning and Structure:* The program is well-planned with detailed steps, and incorporates evaluations to measure success.

Cons:
1. *Measurable Outcomes:* While the concept note presents broad objectives, it might be helpful to have more quantifiable outcomes that can clearly demonstrate the impact of the program.
2. *Financial Aspects:* The concept note doesn't mention the program's financial aspects. As a funder, it would be beneficial to understand the cost-effectiveness of the program.
3. *Sustainability:* While the program's intent is excellent, how will the benefits be sustained post-program? A strategy for long-term impact might enhance the program's value.

In summary, while the concept note outlines a well-structured and potentially beneficial program, it could benefit from including more specific outcomes, post-program support, and financial aspects to strengthen its appeal to both participants and funders.
can you give me a short theory of change supporting the idea of research on the importance of wellbeing and engagement for organizational effectiveness

A theory of change supporting the idea of research on the importance of wellbeing and engagement for organizational effectiveness could look like this:

**Inputs:** Research resources (funding, manpower, time), Organizational data (employee surveys, performance metrics), Wellbeing and engagement programs/initiatives.

**Activities:** Conducting comprehensive studies examining the relationship between employee wellbeing and engagement, and organizational effectiveness. This could include surveys, focus groups, or longitudinal studies on organizational performance. Implement wellbeing and engagement initiatives within organizations and measure their impact over time.

**Outputs:** Research findings that indicate the relationship between wellbeing and engagement, and organizational effectiveness. This might include correlation between high levels of wellbeing and engagement and improved productivity, lower turnover rates, better customer satisfaction, or other key performance indicators. Implementation of successful wellbeing and engagement programs in study organizations.

**Outcomes (Short-term and Medium-term):** Greater awareness and understanding of the importance of wellbeing and engagement in organizational effectiveness among organizational leaders, HR professionals, and employees. Shift in organizational policies to prioritize and invest in wellbeing and engagement initiatives. Improved wellbeing and engagement levels in organizations where initiatives have been implemented.

**Impact (Long-term outcome):** Widespread adoption of wellbeing and engagement practices across organizations, leading to overall higher organizational effectiveness industry-wide. This could manifest as increased productivity, innovation, better customer satisfaction, and lower turnover rates. Over time, this shift could also contribute to broader socio-economic benefits such as reduced healthcare costs, improved mental health across the workforce, and a more vibrant, innovative, and productive economy.

In this theory of change, the research on wellbeing and engagement serves as a crucial catalyst that triggers a chain of events leading to improved organizational effectiveness and broader socio-economic benefits.

Can you condense and summarize this into 4 sentences: This project aims to enhance ISOs' capacity by providing tailored capacity development programs that help them deepen their wellbeing and engagement in their organizations and for the organizations that they serve.
When individuals feel well and engaged, teams thrive. When teams thrive, organizations succeed. By focusing first on individual wellbeing, an upward spiral is created.
Using Bloom’s methodology and tools, the program can successfully enhance the capacity of ISOs and ultimately contribute to the growth of entrepreneurship in Lebanon. By applying tailored wellbeing plans, ISOs will ignite motivation and build purpose. Teams will collaborate better. Productivity will increase. Impact will amplify. Entrepreneurship will flourish.
In summary, wellbeing comes first. Wellbeing drives high performance. High performance drives entrepreneurial growth. By enabling the wellbeing of people within ISOs, this program will transform their capacity to fuel the success of new entrepreneurs and ventures. Individual, team and organization rise together.
The essence of the theory of change in three sentences:
Wellbeing ignites motivation. Motivation amplifies productivity. Productivity accelerates impact.
Through a cycle of human potential unleashed, this program will enhance ISO capacity to best support entrepreneurs. By focusing first on the wellbeing of individuals, teams and organizations will thrive. And as ISOs thrive, entrepreneurship in Lebanon will flourish.

This project will boost the capabilities of Innovation Support Organizations (ISOs) in Lebanon by implementing customized capacity development programs, focusing on individual wellbeing and engagement. Bloom's methodology and tools, utilized in these programs, will spur motivation, foster collaboration, and increase productivity, consequently leading to heightened entrepreneurial growth. Essentially, the theory of change is: wellbeing fuels motivation, motivation boosts productivity, and productivity increases impact. In nurturing the wellbeing of individuals within ISOs, we foster the thriving of teams and organizations, and ultimately catalyze the flourishing of entrepreneurship in Lebanon.
